introduction.p: In this chapter we apply some techniques from algebra to analyze more complicated trigonometric expressions. Before we begin, let's review some algebraic terminology.

ul.li: An algebraic expressionexpressionalgebraic expressionalgebraic expressionexpression is any meaningful collection of numbers, variables, and operation symbols. For example, the height of a golf ball is given in feet by the expression -16t^2 + 64t, where t is the number of seconds after the ball is hit.

We evaluateevaluate an expression by substituting a specific value for the variable or variables involved. Thus, after 1 second, the height of the golf ball is -16(\alert{1})^2 + 64(1\alert{1}) = -16 + 64 = 48~ \text{feet} and after 2 seconds, the height is -16(\alert{2})^2 + 64(\alert{2}) = -64 + 128 = 64~ \text{feet} and so on.

subsection.title: Evaluating Trigonometric Expressions
subsection.p: Trigonometric ratios represent numbers, and they may appear as part of an algebraic expression. Expressions containing trig ratios can be simplified or evaluated like other algebraic expressions.

note.p: Keep in mind that \sin (X), for example, is not a product: it does not mean "sin times X" (whatever that might be). Instead, "sin" is the name of a function, and \sin (X) means to evaluate the sine function at X. Thus, \sin (X) is a single number, the output of the sine function.

statement.p: Evaluate each expression for X = 30\degree and Y = 135\degree.

ol.li: Substituting the values for X and Y, we get 2 \tan (\alert{135\degree}) + 3\sin (\alert{30\degree}) Next, we evaluate each trig ratio and follow the order of operations. 2 \tan (\alert{135\degree}) + 3\sin (\alert{30\degree}) \amp = 2(-1) + 3(\dfrac{1}{2}) \amp= -2 + \dfrac{3}{2} =\dfrac{-1}{2}

This expression includes the product of two trig ratios, \tan (X) \cos (Y). 6\tan (X) \cos (Y)\amp = 6\tan (\alert{30\degree}) \cos (\alert{135\degree}) \amp= 6\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right) \left(\dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \amp =\dfrac{-6}{\sqrt{6}} = -\sqrt{6}

subsection.title: Simplifying Trigonometric Expressions
subsection.p:
When we simplifysimplify an algebraic expression, we obtain a new expression that has the same values as the old one, but is easier to work with. For example, we can apply the distributive law and combine like terms to simplify
2x(x - 6) + 3(x + 2) \amp = 2x^2 - 12x + 3x + 6 \amp = 2x^2 - 9x + 6
The new expression is equivalentequivalent to the old one, that is, the expressions have the same value when we evaluate them at any value of x. For instance, you can check that, at x = \alert{3},
2(\alert{3})(\alert{3} - 6) + 3(\alert{3} + 2)\amp = 6(-3) + 3(5) = -3 \text{and}~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 2(\alert{3})^2 - 9(\alert{3}) + 6 \amp = 18 - 27 + 6 = -3
To simplify an expression containing trig ratios, we treat each ratio as a single variable. Compare the two calculations below:
\amp 8xy\amp \amp -{}\amp\amp 6xy \amp\amp = 2xy \amp 8\cos (\theta) \sin (\theta)\amp \amp -{}\amp \amp 6\cos(\theta) \sin (\theta) \amp \amp = 2\cos (\theta) \sin (\theta)
Both calculations are examples of combining like terms. In the second calculation, we treat \cos (\theta) and \sin (\theta) as variables, just as we treat x and y as variables in the first calculation.

li.p: Combine like terms. 3\tan (A) + 4\tan (A) - 2\cos (A) = 7 \tan (A) - 2\cos (A) Note that \tan (A) and \cos (A) are not like terms.
Combine like terms. 2 - \sin (B) + 2\sin (B) = 2 + \sin (B) Note that ~-\sin (B) is treated as ~-1\cdot \sin (B).

warning.p: In the previous Exercise, note that \cos (t) and \cos (w) are not like terms. (We can choose values for t and w so that \cos (t) and \cos (w) have different values.)

solution.p: We can combine like terms to get 6 \sin (z) - \sin (z) \tan (z) Because 40\degree is not one of the angles for which we know exact trig values, we use a calculator to evaluate the expression. 6 \sin (40\degree) - \sin (40\degree)\tan (40\degree) \amp = 6 (0.6428)(0.8391) \amp = 3.3174

subsection.title: Powers of Trigonometric Ratios
subsection.p: Compare the two expressions \Big(\cos (\theta)\Big)^2~~\text{and}~~~ \cos (\theta^2) They are not the same.

ul.li: The first expression, \Big(\cos (\theta)\Big)^2, says to compute \cos (\theta) and then square the result.
\cos (\theta^2) says to square the angle first, and then compute the cosine.

subsection.p: We usually write \cos^2 (\theta) instead of \left(\cos (\theta)\right)^2, to distinguish it from \cos (\theta^2), and to reduce the number of parentheses.

The same notation applies to the other trig ratios, so that \sin^2 (\theta) = \Big(\sin (\theta)\Big)^2 ~~~\text{and}~~~ \tan^2 (\theta) = \Big(\tan (\theta)\Big)^2 trigonometric functionraising to power
Other powers are written in the same fashion. Thus, for example, \sin^3(\theta) = \Big(\sin (\theta)\Big)^3.

subsection.title: Products
subsection.p: We can multiply together trigonometric expressions, just as we multiply algebraic expressions. Recall that we use the distributive law in computing products such as x(3x - 2) = 3x^2 - 2x and (x - 3)(x + 5) = x^2 + 2x - 15

We can also use the distributive law to multiply binomials that include trig ratios. You may have used the acronym \blert{FOIL}FOIL (acronym: First, Outside, Inside, Last) to remember the four multiplications in a product of binomials:

solution.p: This calculation is similar to the product (4x - 1)(3x+2), except that the variable x has been replaced by \sin (C). Compare the calculations for the two products; first the familiar algebraic product: (4x - 1)(3x + 2) \amp = 4x\cdot 3x + 4x\cdot 2 - 1\cdot 3x - 1\cdot 2 \amp = 12x^2 + 8x - 3x - 2 = 12x^2 + 5x - 2 We compute the product in this example in the same way, but replacing x by \sin (C). \Big(4\sin (C) - 1\Big)\Big(\sin (C) + 2\Big) \amp = \Big(4\sin (C)\Big)\Big(3\sin (C)\Big) + \Big(4\sin (C)\Big)\cdot 2 - 1\Big(3\sin (C)\Big) - 1\cdot 2 \amp = 12\sin^2 (C) + 5\sin (C) - 2

subsection.title: Factoring
subsection.p: We can factor trigonometric expressions with the same techniques we use for algebraic expressions. In the next two Examples, compare the familiar algebraic factoring with a similar trigonometric expression.

li.p: We factor out the common factor, 3w. 6w^2 - 9w = 3w(2w-3)
We factor out the common factor, 3\sin (\theta). 6\sin^2 (\theta)- 9\sin (\theta) = 3\sin (\theta)\Big(2\sin (\theta)-3\Big)

subsection.p: We can also factor quadratic trinomials.

li.p: We look for numbers p and q so that (t + p)(t + q) = t^2 - 3t - 10. Their product is pq = -10, and their sum is p + q = -3. By checking the factors of -10 for the correct sum, we find p = -5 and q = 2. Thus, t^2 - 3t - 10 = (t - 5)(t + 2)
Now replace t by \tan (\alpha) to find \tan^2 (\alpha) - 3\tan (\alpha) - 10 = \Big(\tan (\alpha) - 5\Big)\Big(\tan (\alpha) + 2\Big)
